courseDescr: Business Leadership for Lawyers in the Age of AI. With the emergence and growth of artificial intelligence in business strategy, operations, and governance, the need for lawyers to function not simply as compliance and regulatory experts but as business leaders and partners is foundational both to the success of the enterprises they help lead and to enduring societal benefit. This course prepares future leaders to guide, govern, and operationalize artificial intelligence with the purpose of engaging in key "real world" challenges and approaches to address derisking, shaping, governing, and enabling AI leadership in the private sector. Focus is geared not towards the deep technologist or the privacy/IP/regulatory specialist, but on the future general counsel and/or business leader who is interested in studying real world business issues in the rapidly changing landscape of AI. With an interdisciplinary approach, we will consider business, strategic, operational, financial, governance, and other emerging issues. The class format will involve practical case studies and projects and will include guest speakers, AI practitioners, and thought leaders from business, technology, law, and governance. The goal is to equip future lawyers to act as essential strategic leaders in enabling the effective, responsible, and beneficial use of AI into the future. Special Instructions: Students on the waitlist for the course will be admitted if spots are available on the basis of priority and degree program. Elements used in grading: Attendance, class participation, written assignments, final paper. Case study development, simulations, final presentation (written and oral).
courseTitle: Business Leadership for Lawyers in the Age of AI

courseDescr: (LAW 1047) Large corporations now routinely spend millions of dollars to protect human rights and the environment. Shell Nigeria builds hospitals and schools in the Niger Delta. Nike employs hundreds of inspectors to improve conditions for the factory workers who produce its shoes across Asia and Latin America. Technology companies such as Facebook have scrambled to fend off the threat of new regulation since the Cambridge Analytica revelations. Other examples abound, across industries and around the globe. "Don't be evil" (Google's former motto) may be one motivation for these companies, but something more mundane is also at work: many companies believe they will do well, financially, if they do good, ethically. This course examines questions that lawyers in large law firms, corporations, NGOs, and government agencies regularly confront: --What does it mean for a company to "do good"? Should it care? --When does it serve a company's interest to take costly action to address human rights, labor, and environmental concerns? --What tactics have activists used to shift public opinion, media frames, and the law, and thereby change companies' incentives? We will learn through seminar-style discussion, lectures, role play, and small group exercises. Several guest speakers with experience in business, advocacy, or in between will provide insights from their experiences on the ground. Special Instructions: Students have the option to write a long research paper in lieu of the final exam with consent of instructor. Elements used in grading: Class Participation, Written Assignments; Final Exam or Final Paper. Undergraduate students interested in this subject should enroll in HUMRTS 115 instead. Enrollment in this course is limited to graduate and professional students, who need the consent of the instructor, Jamie O'Connell (joconnell@law.stanford.edu).
courseTitle: Business, Social Responsibility, and Human Rights

The shoe's global supply chain and production process make it a meaningful representation.

courseDescr: Large corporations now routinely spend millions of dollars to protect human rights and the environment. Shell Nigeria builds hospitals and schools in the Niger Delta. Nike employs hundreds of inspectors to improve conditions for the factory workers who produce its shoes across Asia and Latin America. Technology companies such as Facebook have scrambled to fend off the threat of new regulation since the Cambridge Analytica revelations. Other examples abound, across industries and around the globe. "Don't be evil" (Google's former motto) may be one motivation for these companies, but something more mundane is also at work: many companies believe they will do well, financially, if they do good, ethically. This course examines questions that lawyers in large law firms, corporations, NGOs, and government agencies regularly confront: --How does business activity affect human rights and other "social" goods (such as the environment and community cohesion)? --What factors, internal and external to companies, shape corporate decisions that have human rights/social impacts? When does it serve a company's interest to take costly action to address human rights, labor, and environmental concerns? -- What tactics have activists used to shift public opinion, media frames, and the law, and thereby change companies' incentives? We will learn through seminar-style discussion, lectures, role play, and small group exercises. Several guest speakers with experience in business, advocacy, or in between will provide insights from their experiences on the ground. Special Instructions: Students have the option to write a long research paper in lieu of the final exam with consent of instructor. After the term begins, students enrolled in the course can transfer from section (01) into section (02), which meets the R requirement, with consent of the instructor. Elements used in grading: Class Participation, Written Assignments; Final Exam or Final Paper. Cross-listed with International Policy (INTLPOL 358).
courseTitle: Business, Social Responsibility, and Human Rights

courseDescr: In-class lectures and guest speakers who work in the Buy-Side to explore the synergies amongst the various players, roles, risk appetites, and investment time and return horizons. We aim to see the forest and the different species of trees growing in the forest known as the Buy-Side, so as to develop a perspective as financial engineers for how the ecosystem functions, what risks it digests, how it generates capital at what rate and amount for the Sell-Side, and how impacts in the real economy are reflected - or should be reflected - in the culture and risk models adopted by the Buy-Side participants.
rewritten_descr_q1: A prism embodies the Buy-Side Investing course, as it refracts light into various components, symbolizing the diverse players and roles. Its angular design represents the complexities and synergies among participants, while its ability to reveal hidden patterns reflects the course's goal of understanding the ecosystem's functioning and risk management, illuminating the interconnectedness of the Buy-Side and its impact on the economy clearly always.
rewritten_descr_q2: The 2008 financial crisis illuminates the Buy-Side's risk appetite and return horizons. Excessive leverage and poor risk models led to significant losses, highlighting the importance of robust risk management and capital generation. This event showcases the ecosystem's functioning, risk digestion, and impact on the real economy, making it a compelling example for financial engineers to develop informed perspectives on the Buy-Side's role and responsibilities.
rewritten_descr_q3: The annual Berkshire Hathaway shareholder meeting reveals insights into Buy-Side investing concepts. Its traditions, such as open discussions and long-term focus, reflect underlying themes of risk appetite and investment horizons, demonstrating a unique cultural practice that prioritizes value creation and patient capital, influencing the Buy-Side ecosystem and its participants' risk models and investment strategies slowly over time with lasting impacts.
rewritten_descr_q4: Behavioral finance is a related concept, connecting to Buy-Side Investing's core themes. Understanding cognitive biases and emotional influences on investment decisions can deepen comprehension of risk appetites and investment horizons, revealing how psychological factors impact the ecosystem's functioning, capital generation, and risk models, ultimately informing more nuanced financial engineering strategies and decision-making processes within the Buy-Side industry and its interactions.

courseDescr: Introduction to differential calculus of functions of one variable. Review of elementary functions (including exponentials and logarithms), limits, rates of change, the derivative and its properties, applications of the derivative. Prerequisites: periodic trigonometric functions, advanced algebra, and analysis of elementary functions (including exponentials and logarithms).
rewritten_descr_q1: A speedometer embodies the key idea of rates of change in calculus. Its design measures instantaneous velocity, illustrating the derivative's concept. The speedometer's needle moves in response to acceleration, demonstrating the relationship between rates of change and the derivative's properties, making it a meaningful representation of calculus principles in a real-world application, with its characteristics and use reflecting fundamental calculus concepts precisely.
rewritten_descr_q2: Isaac Newton's development of calculus in the 17th century revolutionized mathematics. His work on rates of change and the derivative transformed science. Key aspects include his method of fluxions, which described functions and their rates of change, and its application to physics, making it a compelling example of calculus in action, illustrating its power and significance in understanding the natural world precisely.
rewritten_descr_q3: Japanese tea ceremonies reflect calculus concepts, as precise rates of change in temperature and ingredient ratios create optimal flavors, illustrating limits and derivatives in a traditional setting, where meticulous attention to detail and respect for process mirror the discipline's focus on incremental analysis and optimization, revealing harmony between cultural practice and mathematical principles in a serene environment. Calculus principles are subtly embedded.
rewritten_descr_q4: Optimization techniques are not explicitly covered, but connect to calculus' core themes. Understanding optimization deepens comprehension of rates of change and the derivative, allowing students to apply calculus to real-world problems, such as maximizing or minimizing functions, and expands their ability to model and analyze complex phenomena, making calculus more relevant and applicable to various fields and disciplines effectively always.

courseDescr: The definite integral, Riemann sums, antiderivatives, the Fundamental Theorem of Calculus. Integration by substitution and by parts. Area between curves, and volume by slices, washers, and shells. Initial-value problems, exponential and logistic models, direction fields, and parametric curves.
rewritten_descr_q1: A waterwheel embodies calculus concepts, particularly integration. Its curved blades and rotational motion illustrate area between curves and volume calculations. The waterwheel's design and use demonstrate exponential and logistic models, showcasing direction fields and parametric curves. Its functionality relies on antiderivatives and the Fundamental Theorem of Calculus, making it a meaningful representation of calculus principles in a physical, real-world application always.
rewritten_descr_q2: The development of calculus by Newton and Leibniz showcases the Fundamental Theorem. Their work on Riemann sums and antiderivatives led to breakthroughs in integration and differentiation. This historical event highlights key concepts, demonstrating the power of calculus in modeling real-world phenomena, such as exponential growth and logistic curves, with precise mathematical formulations and solutions emerging from their pioneering efforts and discoveries slowly.
rewritten_descr_q3: Japanese tea ceremonies reflect calculus concepts, as precise measurements and deliberate movements illustrate integration's attention to detail. The ritual's repetitive patterns and subtle variations evoke the concept of limits, while the ceremony's harmonious balance mirrors the optimization problems solved through calculus, revealing a cultural appreciation for precision and balance in everyday life and traditions slowly.
rewritten_descr_q4: Chaos theory connects to calculus core themes. Understanding chaos theory deepens comprehension of exponential models and initial-value problems, revealing complex behaviors and sensitivities. It expands comprehension of logistic models, illustrating unpredictable outcomes and intricate patterns, enriching calculus understanding with real-world applications and complexities, fostering nuanced problem-solving skills and insights. Calculus provides foundation for chaos theory, enhancing analytical capabilities and critical thinking, broadly applicable.

courseDescr: This course addresses a variety of topics centered around the theme of "calculus with infinite processes", largely the content of BC-level AP Calculus that isn't in the AB-level syllabus. It is needed throughout probability and statistics at all levels, as well as to understand approximation procedures that arise in all quantitative fields (including economics and computer graphics). After an initial review of limit rules, the course goes on to discuss sequences of numbers and of functions, as well as limits "at infinity" for each (needed for any sensible discussion of long-term behavior of a numerical process, such as: iterative procedures and complexity in computer science, dynamic models throughout economics, and repeated trials with data in any field). Integration is discussed for rational functions (a loose end from Math 20) and especially (improper) integrals for unbounded functions and "to infinity": this shows up in contexts as diverse as escape velocity for a rocket, the present value of a perpetual yield asset, and important calculations in probability (including the famous "bell curve" and to understand why many statistical tests work as they do). The course then turns to infinite series (how to "sum" an infinite collection of numbers), some useful convergence and divergence rests for these, and the associated killer app: power series and their properties, as well as Taylor approximations, all of which provide the framework that underlies virtually all mathematical models used in any quantitative field.
rewritten_descr_q1: A rocket embodies a key idea in calculus, as its escape velocity is calculated using improper integrals. Its design and launch trajectory rely on mathematical models, making it a meaningful representation of calculus principles. The rocket's infinite possibilities in space reflect the infinite series and limits explored in the course, connecting calculus to real-world applications. Calculus enables rocket precision.
rewritten_descr_q2: The development of calculus by Newton and Leibniz showcases infinite processes. Their work on limits and series enabled breakthroughs in physics and mathematics, demonstrating calculus's power in modeling real-world phenomena, such as motion and optimization, with precise calculations and predictions, forever changing quantitative fields like economics and computer science with enduring impact.
rewritten_descr_q3: Japanese tea ceremonies reflect calculus concepts, as the deliberate, sequential steps mirror limit rules and infinite processes, while the ritual's repetition and attention to detail illustrate convergence and series, revealing the beauty in mathematical precision and tradition. The ceremony's patterns and social functions embody the course themes of approximation and iteration. Tradition and math intersect.
rewritten_descr_q4: Fractals are not explicitly covered, but connect to calculus' core themes. Understanding fractals deepens comprehension of infinite series and power series, as they rely on self-similar patterns and infinite iterations, illustrating complex mathematical concepts in a visual and intuitive way, expanding comprehension of calculus' underlying principles and applications. This connection enriches understanding of quantitative fields like economics and computer science.

courseDescr: 'A place belongs forever to whoever claims it hardest,' writes Joan Didion, 'remembers it most obsessively, wrenches it from itself, shapes it, renders it, loves it so radically that he remakes it in his image.' From the Gold Rush to Hollywood to Silicon Valley, Yosemite to the Salton Sea, in this course we'll encounter a series of writers and artists whose work is set in California, or participates in its imagining, and throughout consider how culture and a sense of place are closely related. How does a novel, photograph, or film conjure a landscape or community? When we think of California, whose stories are included, and whose are left out? Possible texts: works by Mary Austin, Cesar Chavez, Mike Davis, the Depression-era Federal Writers Project, Rebecca Solnit, and John Steinbeck; films: Sunset Boulevard, Clueless, and There Will Be Blood; and the art of Carlton Watkins, Dorothea Lange, Richard Misrach, and Chiura Obata. For the final paper, students will write about a California place of their choice.
rewritten_descr_q1: A vintage camera embodies the course theme, as it captures California's landscape and community, reflecting the relationship between culture and place. Its lens and shutter represent the selective storytelling and inclusion/exclusion of narratives, echoing the course's exploration of whose stories are told and whose are left out, making it a meaningful representation of the course's key ideas.
rewritten_descr_q2: The Gold Rush exemplifies California's complex relationship with place and culture. Mass migration and exploitation of land and people raised questions about ownership and belonging, highlighting whose stories are included and whose are left out, shaping the state's identity and informing the works of writers and artists, such as Mary Austin and John Steinbeck, who wrote about its impact.
rewritten_descr_q3: The cultural practice of storytelling in California reveals insights into course concepts. Traditions of oral storytelling reflect community patterns and social functions, highlighting whose stories are included and excluded. This practice reflects underlying themes of place, identity, and culture, showcasing the complex relationships between Californians and their landscape, and how these interactions shape the state's narrative and sense of belonging always.
rewritten_descr_q4: Gentrification is a related concept, as it affects the culture and sense of place in California. Understanding gentrification can deepen comprehension of how California's landscape and communities are shaped and represented, highlighting power dynamics and whose stories are included or excluded, and how this impacts the state's identity and imagination in literature, art, and film, and the lives of its residents and visitors daily.

courseDescr: Focus is on the lyric and epic poetry of Portugal's national poet, Luís de Camoes (1524?-1580). Topics include Portugal's Asian empire, Iberian humanism, classical reception, Neoplatonism, and the limits of poetry. Readings include Camoes's epic masterpiece, Os Lusiadas, alongside his expansive and innovative lyric production. Readings in Portuguese and English. Taught in English.
rewritten_descr_q1: The astrolabe embodies the course's theme of exploration and empire. Its intricate design and navigational use represent the intersection of humanism and classical reception, reflecting Camoes's poetic mastery of maritime discovery and cultural exchange, with its brass body and etched lines symbolizing the fusion of art and science in Portugal's Asian empire, making it a meaningful representation of the course's key ideas and principles always.
rewritten_descr_q2: The discovery of the sea route to India in 1498 illuminates Portugal's Asian empire theme. Vasco da Gama's voyage established trade and cultural exchange, shaping Camoes's Os Lusiadas. This event's aspects, such as navigation and colonization, demonstrate Portugal's imperial ambitions, making it a compelling example of Iberian humanism and classical reception in Camoes's work, influencing his epic poetry and lyric production significantly always.
rewritten_descr_q3: Fado music reveals insights into Portugal's cultural identity, reflecting themes of nostalgia and saudade, echoing Camoes's lyric poetry. Its traditions and patterns evoke a sense of longing, resonating with Os Lusiadas's exploration of empire and humanism, while its social functions bring communities together, illustrating the power of artistic expression to shape national identity and cultural heritage, mirroring course concepts.
rewritten_descr_q4: Globalization is a related concept, connecting to Portugal's Asian empire and Iberian humanism. Understanding globalization can deepen comprehension of Camoes's works, revealing how cultural exchange and imperialism influenced his poetry, and expanding analysis of Os Lusiadas and lyric production, offering new perspectives on classical reception and Neoplatonism, and the poet's innovative style, within a broader historical context, and its lasting impact on literature.

courseDescr: This course examines the theory and practice of American campaigns and elections. First, we will attempt to explain the behavior of the key players -- candidates, parties, journalists, and voters -- in terms of the institutional arrangements and political incentives that confront them. Second, we will use current and recent election campaigns as "laboratories" for testing generalizations about campaign strategy and voter behavior. Third, we examine selections from the academic literature dealing with the origins of partisan identity, electoral design, and the immediate effects of campaigns on public opinion, voter turnout, and voter choice. As well, we'll explore issues of electoral reform and their more long-term consequences for governance and the political process.
rewritten_descr_q1: A voting booth embodies the course theme, representing democratic participation. Its design ensures secrecy and fairness, reflecting key principles of American elections. The booth's physical presence signifies the intersection of individual choice and collective governance, making it a meaningful representation of the course's exploration of campaigns, voting, and elections, and the complexities of democratic decision-making processes always at play.
rewritten_descr_q2: The 2016 US presidential election is a compelling example, highlighting campaign strategy and voter behavior. Candidates' tactics and media coverage influenced public opinion, voter turnout, and choice. The election's outcome and subsequent analysis illuminate partisan identity, electoral design, and governance consequences, making it a significant case study for understanding American campaigns and elections dynamics and their long-term effects on the political process and system.
rewritten_descr_q3: Voting is a cultural practice revealing insights into campaign strategies and voter behavior. Its traditions and patterns reflect underlying themes of partisan identity, electoral design, and public opinion. Social functions of voting, such as community engagement, also reflect course concepts, influencing governance and the political process through electoral reform and voter turnout, shaping the democratic experience and its long-term consequences.
rewritten_descr_q4: Social media influence is a related concept, connecting to campaign strategy and voter behavior. Understanding its impact can deepen comprehension of elections, as it shapes public opinion, voter turnout, and choice, ultimately affecting governance and the political process, revealing new avenues for electoral reform and partisan identity formation. This expands the course's core themes, offering a nuanced view of modern elections.

courseDescr: Required of and limited to first- and second-year graduate students in Cancer Biology. Recent papers in the literature presented by graduate students. When possible, discussion relates to and precedes cancer-related seminars at Stanford. Attendance at the relevant seminar required.
rewritten_descr_q1: A microscope embodies Cancer Biology Journal Club, as it represents the detailed examination of cellular structures. Its design enables precise observation, mirroring the course's in-depth analysis of recent research papers. The microscope's use in cancer research makes it a meaningful representation, symbolizing the pursuit of understanding cancer biology through meticulous investigation and discussion of relevant literature and seminars, reflecting the course's themes and principles precisely always.
rewritten_descr_q2: The discovery of the BRCA1 gene is a historical event illuminating cancer biology. Aspects of this event include collaborative research and genetic analysis. Actions taken led to identification of genetic mutations. Outcomes include improved cancer screening and treatment, making it a compelling example of advancements in cancer research and biology, highlighting the importance of scientific collaboration and discovery in understanding cancer.
rewritten_descr_q3: The Japanese tradition of mentorship reflects Cancer Biology Journal Club themes. Senpai-kohai relationships demonstrate hierarchical learning, where experienced mentors guide junior students, mirroring graduate students presenting papers to peers, fostering discussion and growth, and highlighting the importance of community and knowledge sharing in scientific inquiry and academic progression, promoting collaborative learning and professional development, and social bonding among students.
rewritten_descr_q4: Epigenetics is a related concept, influencing cancer development and progression. Understanding epigenetics deepens comprehension of cancer biology by revealing gene expression regulation mechanisms, expanding knowledge of tumor formation and behavior, and informing therapeutic strategies, ultimately enhancing analysis of journal articles and seminar discussions, fostering a more nuanced understanding of cancer biology principles and applications. This connection enriches the learning experience, broadening perspectives on cancer research.

courseDescr: Prerequisites: Must be a junior, senior, or graduate student to enroll or consent of instructor. Clinical epidemiological methods relevant to human research in cancer will be the focus. The concepts of risk; case control, cohort, and cross-sectional studies; clinical trials; bias; confounding; interaction; screening; and causal inference will be introduced and applied. Social, political, economic, and ethical controversies surrounding cancer screening, prevention, and research will be considered. HUMBIO 154 courses can be taken separately or as a series.
rewritten_descr_q1: A microscope embodies Cancer Epidemiology, representing the scientific method and research. Its precise design and use enable detailed examination of cells, illustrating the concept of risk and causal inference. The microscope's ability to reveal hidden patterns and structures makes it a meaningful representation of the course's focus on clinical epidemiological methods and cancer research. It symbolizes the pursuit of knowledge and understanding in cancer epidemiology precisely always.
rewritten_descr_q2: The Tuskegee Syphilis Study illuminates ethical controversies in cancer research. Uninformed black men were left untreated, highlighting issues of consent, bias, and confounding. This study's actions and outcomes demonstrate the need for rigorous clinical trials and ethical consideration, making it a compelling example of the importance of responsible research practices in cancer epidemiology and beyond, informing modern standards.
rewritten_descr_q3: The Japanese tea ceremony reveals insights into cancer epidemiology concepts. Its traditions emphasize mindfulness and screening, reflecting themes of prevention and early detection. The ritual's patterns and social functions promote community interaction, illustrating cohort study principles and social support's role in cancer research, while also highlighting cultural influences on health behaviors and outcomes, and the importance of considering these factors in epidemiological studies always.
rewritten_descr_q4: Genomics is a related concept not explicitly covered, connecting to cancer epidemiology's core themes. Understanding genomics can deepen comprehension of cancer risk, screening, and prevention by revealing genetic predispositions and interactions with environmental factors, ultimately informing targeted interventions and personalized medicine approaches in cancer research and treatment. This intersection enhances epidemiological studies and public health strategies. Genetic factors influence disease susceptibility.

courseDescr: This course takes students on a trip to major capital cities at different moments in time, including Renaissance Florence, Golden Age Madrid, colonial Mexico City, imperial Beijing, Enlightenment and romantic Paris, existential and revolutionary St. Petersburg, roaring Berlin, modernist Vienna, and transnational Dakar. While exploring each place in a particular historical moment, we will also consider the relations between culture, power, and social life. How does the cultural life of a country intersect with the political activity of a capital? How do large cities shape our everyday experience, our aesthetic preferences, and our sense of history? Why do some cities become cultural capitals? Primary materials for this course will consist of literary, visual, sociological, and historical documents (in translation). No prerequisites.
courseTitle: CAPITALS: How Cities Shape Cultures, States, and People
courseCodes: COMPLIT 100 / DLCL 100 / FRENCH 175 / GERMAN 175 / HISTORY 106E / ILAC 175 / ITALIAN 175 / URBANST 153
rewritten_descr_q1: The Eiffel Tower embodies the course theme, symbolizing cultural and political intersection. Its iron lattice design represents industrial modernity, while its iconic status reflects Paris' cultural capital. Built for the 1889 World's Fair, it showcases the city's engineering prowess and artistic flair, exemplifying how urban landscapes shape our experience and sense of history, making it a meaningful representation of the course's key ideas and principles always.
rewritten_descr_q2: The French Revolution in Paris is a compelling example, showcasing how a capital city shapes culture and power. Key aspects include the storming of the Bastille, Napoleon's rise, and the subsequent transformation of Paris' aesthetic and social landscape, illustrating the intersection of politics and culture in a capital city, influencing everyday life and historical sense. Historical documents and literary works provide insight.
rewritten_descr_q3: The carnival in Rio de Janeiro reveals insights into course themes, showcasing cultural life and power intersections. Its traditions and patterns reflect social functions, such as community bonding and aesthetic expression, highlighting how large cities shape everyday experience and sense of history, making some cities cultural capitals through vibrant cultural practices and rituals that intersect with political activity. Cultural life is showcased.
rewritten_descr_q4: Globalization is a concept connecting to the course's core themes. Understanding globalization can deepen comprehension of how capital cities shape cultures, as it reveals the complex networks and exchanges between cities, influencing their cultural and social dynamics, and allowing for a more nuanced exploration of the intersections between culture, power, and social life in these urban centers over time and space constantly.

courseDescr: Students will conduct research and write an extended research paper on a topic in international relations. A wide range of topics and research methods can be pursued. The prototypical capstone paper will build off of and further develop a research paper that had been written for another Stanford course. Students who wish to research a new topic need to have that research question and methodology conceived and approved prior to course enrollment. All students will fill out an application during the fall quarter to ensure research questions and designs are acceptable by the first day of class. This course satisfies the capstone requirement for the Program in International Relations.
rewritten_descr_q1: A globe embodies the Capstone Paper course, representing international relations and global connections. Its spherical design and mapped surface symbolize the interconnectedness of nations and cultures, reflecting the course's focus on researching and analyzing international topics, fostering a deeper understanding of global dynamics and relationships, and encouraging exploration. The globe's complexity mirrors the course's in-depth research requirements and methodologies.
rewritten_descr_q2: The Cuban Missile Crisis illuminates diplomacy in international relations. Key aspects include secret negotiations, naval blockades, and compromise. The crisis showcases the importance of effective communication, strategic decision-making, and cooperation, making it a compelling example of crisis management and conflict resolution in international relations, highlighting the complexities of global politics and diplomacy. It demonstrates the need for careful analysis and effective policy implementation.
rewritten_descr_q3: The Japanese tea ceremony reveals insights into international relations concepts, showcasing traditions of respect and diplomacy. rewritten_descr_q4: Global governance is a related concept, connecting to international relations core themes. This enhances research validity and relevance in the field of international relations significantly always.

courseDescr: Students will work in project teams on problems central to the mission of an SF-based international NGO that employs community-driven and policy-level strategies to protect people and the environment from harm caused by internationally financed development projects. Students will visit the NGO, learn about international development and accountability problems, and in the end present a policy report. The course is open only to IR majors and capped at 12 students, with priority given to seniors. This is a Cardinal Course certified by the Haas Center for Public Service. To apply for enrollment, please complete the brief application form.
rewritten_descr_q1: A globe embodies the course's theme of international development, representing interconnectedness and global impact. Its spherical design symbolizes unity and wholeness, while its mapped surface highlights diverse countries and regions, illustrating the complexities of international finance and policy. It serves as a meaningful representation of the course's focus on global issues and community-driven strategies, connecting local actions to worldwide consequences effectively always.
rewritten_descr_q2: The Bhopal disaster exemplifies harm caused by development projects. In 1984, a gas leak in India killed thousands, highlighting accountability issues. This event showcases the need for policy-level strategies to protect people and the environment, making it a compelling example for the Capstone Policy Practicum, illustrating the importance of community-driven solutions and international development accountability. It sparks critical thinking and informed policy report development.
rewritten_descr_q3: Community-driven development projects reveal insights into accountability and policy strategies. Local traditions and patterns reflect underlying themes of environmental protection and social justice, demonstrating the importance of culturally sensitive approaches to international development, and highlighting the need for inclusive and responsible policy-making practices that prioritize community needs and well-being in development projects and policies implementation effectively always.
rewritten_descr_q4: Environmental justice is a concept not explicitly covered, connecting to the course's core themes. Understanding environmental justice can deepen comprehension of development projects' impacts on communities, highlighting power dynamics and inequality, and expanding students' analysis of policy strategies to protect people and the environment, promoting more nuanced and effective solutions, and broadening their perspective on accountability and community-driven initiatives globally always.

courseDescr: Students can fulfill the capstone requirement by completing an individually designed capstone project. Students will enroll in a seminar (POLISCI 290A, 290B, or 290C) and, as part of that class, produce an original project that integrates and applies knowledge of political science. In most cases, the capstone project will be a research paper that builds on prior coursework, overseas studies, or an internship. Other types of projects may qualify, with approval from the department. Enrollment in the capstone project seminar will be limited to juniors and seniors (with priority to seniors) majoring in political science. Before enrolling, each student must submit, and the department must approve, a description of the intended capstone project.
rewritten_descr_q1: A leather-bound book embodies the Capstone Project's emphasis on research and knowledge integration. Its worn cover and filled pages represent the culmination of prior coursework, while its binding symbolizes the connection of ideas, making it a meaningful representation of the course's themes of academic rigor and intellectual synthesis, reflecting the student's growth and understanding of political science concepts and principles always.
rewritten_descr_q2: The Watergate scandal is a compelling example, illuminating themes of political power and accountability. Key aspects include Nixon's actions, Congressional investigations, and the resignation outcome, demonstrating the application of political science knowledge to real-world events, highlighting the importance of checks and balances, and showcasing the impact of individual actions on political systems and governance structures effectively.
rewritten_descr_q3: The cultural practice of town hall meetings reveals insights into political science concepts. Its traditions of open discussion and debate reflect underlying themes of civic engagement and democracy. Patterns of active participation and social functions of community building demonstrate the importance of citizen involvement in governance, echoing course themes of political participation and representation, and highlighting the value of collective decision-making.
rewritten_descr_q4: Public policy implementation is a related concept, connecting to the capstone project's core themes. Understanding this idea deepens comprehension of political science by revealing how research informs decision-making, and how policies are translated into action, expanding students' knowledge of the field's practical applications and real-world impact significantly always.

courseDescr: Required for, and limited to, E-IPER Joint MS and Dual MS students. Propose, conduct and publicly present final individual or team projects demonstrating the integration of the knowledge and skills of the E-IPER MS with the student's joint or dual degree (e.g., MBA, JD, MD, MIP, other MA/MS, or PhD). Presentation at the Week 10 Capstone Symposium and submission of the final product required. Please reach out to the E-IPER MS Lecturer for an add code.
courseTitle: Capstone Project Seminar in Environment and Resources
rewritten_descr_q1: A globe embodies the Capstone Project Seminar's theme of integrating environmental knowledge with other fields. Outcomes, such as increased regulation, make it a compelling example of the need for interdisciplinary approaches to environmental issues, aligning with the E-IPER MS program's focus on integrated problem-solving and collaboration across disciplines and sectors effectively.
rewritten_descr_q3: The Japanese tea ceremony reveals insights into environmental stewardship, reflecting course themes of sustainability and resource management. Its traditions and patterns promote mindfulness, respect, and harmony with nature, echoing the course's focus on integrating knowledge and skills to address environmental challenges and promote sustainable practices, demonstrating a cultural practice that values the environment.
